Stem: Branching, whitish to pale-green, hairy when young becoming more sparse with age.
Leaves: Up to 25 cm long initially in rosette, smaller above. Lance shaped, dark green and deeply divided. Wooly when young, becoming less hairy with age. Rough textured.
Flowers: Tightly packed purple or pinkish white in stalkless thistle-like heads. Surrounded by greenish to brownish bracts with long sharp spines.
FruitSeeds: Whitish or greyish seeds with brownish blotches or streaks. Egg-shaped, smooth and without hairs or scales.
Habitat: Pastures, cropping kand, roadsides, grasslands, open woodlands, waste land.
DistinguishingFeatures: Distinguished from other Knapweeds (*Centaurea* species) by having purple flowers in combination with long spines on the bracts surrounding the flower. Also distinguished by having smooth rather than bristled or hairy seeds.
